Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fundamental Studies of Multidentate Halogen Bond Donors for Supramolecular Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Berryman of the University of Montana, conducts research to gain a better fundamental understanding of the interactions between molecules and to provide insights for developing novel approaches to accelerate chemical reactions. This research aims to develop a new class of catalysts for more efficient synthesis of sulfur containing compounds. Considering the wide range of useful sulfur containing pharmaceuticals, this research has the potential to help advance drug development and benefit society. Additionally, educational and outreach activities are designed to inspire students and broaden participation in science fields. Specifically, 3D printed models of crystal structures are used as an interactive learning tool at the spectrUM science museum and on Native American reservations. 3D printed models are also used to facilitate the teaching of X-ray crystallography in university courses and help high school students understand the concepts of molecular recognition and shape selectivity.

The Berryman group performs studies to obtain a fundamental understanding of the strength, structure and nature of halogen bonding interactions between organic donors and soft chalcogen and pnictogen Lewis bases. His group further investigates whether multidentate halogen bonding receptors can selectively bind and catalyze the reactions of soft substrates. An important goal of this research is to address the question of whether halogen bonding interactions can be developed into a new genre of organocatalysis. The goal of the broader impacts is to develop hands-on methods to teach X-ray crystallography and inspire underrepresented students to explore science education. A tactile approach improves students? basic understanding of structure and appreciation of chemistry. 3D printing technology is exploited to translate crystal structure coordinates into tangible models that can be visualized, held and manipulated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of synthetic supramolecular chemistry continues to advance towards more complex and dynamic assemblies of molecules. One of the long standing goals in this field is to develop small organic molecules that function as catalysts that speed up chemical reactions. To expand the scope and reactivity of these catalysts, researchers strive to use new noncovalent interactions in novel ways to change the properties of these catalysts. A secondary benefit of studying these new nocovalent interactions is that one learns new ways to control the form and thus the function of new molecules.

The Berryman lab uses their expertise in molecular design, synthetic chemistry, X-ray crystallography, computational chemistry and solution studies to build and understand new molecules. This project has produced many examples of organic molecules that bind anionic and neutral guest molecules that can catalyze reactions and spontaneously fold into helical structures.

The intellectual merit resulting from this grant includes (1) The development of new receptor molecules that bind anions and also function as catalysts; (2) the development of a new approach to control molecular conformation and binding strength by positioning hydrogen bonding and halogen bonding functionality in close proximity; (3) the discovery of higher order anion binding triple helicate molecules and the significance of halogen bonding functionality in assembling these complexes; and (4) the importance of different functional groups on modulating the properties of these molecules.  

We used these strong foundational fundamental studies to optimize the catalytic function of a hydrogen and halogen bonding small molecule to accelerate a halide abstraction reaction. Thus, we showed that halogen bonding can be used to catalyze reactions and that the positioning of other noncovalent interactions is critically important in optimizing the catalytic function. This strategy is not limited to this example but can be applied to other catalyst designs and host molecules.

The broader impacts from this research include (1) a robust outreach program with a local science museum where local middle school kids come to the University of Montana to participate in lab tours and chemical experiments; (2) training of graduate students and undergraduate researchers who went on to careers in STEM; and (3) the development of tactile teaching and outreach activities through the use of 3D-printing of models of molecules.
